ynein.
But how does a cilium work? Experiments have indicated that ciliary mo-
tion results from the chemically-powered “walking” of the dynein arms on one
microtubule up the neighboring subfiber B of a second microtubule so that the
two  microtubules  slide  past  each  other  (Figure  20.2).  However,  the  protein
cross-links between microtubules in an intact cilium prevent neighboring mi-
crotubules from sliding past each other by more than a short distance. These
